Award.AwardTitle: Conference on low-dimensional topology and geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation award provides travel support for speakers and participants in the Conference on Low-dimensional Topology and Geometry held at Vanderbilt University from May 15 to May 19, 2017. Topology and geometry are central areas of mathematics that have been the focus of active research for centuries. Topology concerns the mathematical properties of spaces ranging from the physical, like the surface of a doughnut, to the abstract, like the space of configurations of robots in a factory or the space of functions that satisfy a differential equation. Geometry concerns abstract or concrete notions distance or length, such as the amount of energy to move between two configurations of robots. Topology and geometry enjoy particularly rich interactions in low dimensions, and these connections have been a source of profound discoveries in both fields. The main objective of the conference is to bring together leading experts who have made substantial contributions in low-dimensional topology and geometry and to provide a platform to present recent results and propose future directions of research. The conference is organized in conjunction with the 32nd Shanks Lecture, which will be delivered by Professor Ian Agol (University of California, Berkeley). This award provides opportunities for mathematicians from underrepresented groups and researchers that are early in their career or lack other sources of travel support to attend and participate in the conference.

The conference will focus on important developments in low-dimensional topology and geometry, with emphasis on the powerful negative curvature and combinatorial techniques that have driven many recent advances. Topics will include, but are not limited to, hyperbolic 3-manifolds, moduli spaces of Riemann surfaces, mapping class groups, the geometry and topology of curves on surfaces, surface bundles, Gromov-hyperbolic simplicial complexes, and CAT(0) cube complexes. The activities will include nineteen keynote talks and the Shanks lecture, with ample time for questions and discussion. The combination of topics and speakers will attract numerous participants and will afford students and recent PhDs an excellent opportunity to interact with and learn from leaders in these fields. More information is available at the conference website: https://my.vanderbilt.edu/shanks2017/

POR.DRECONTENT:
From May 15-19, 2017, the Vanderbilt University Department of Mathematics hosted an international conference titled "Low-Dimensional Topology and Geometry.'' The conference was held in conjunction with the 32nd annual Shanks Lecture, delivered by Ian Agol from the University of California, Berkeley.The conference was partially funded by the NSF and received additional funding from the Shanks Endowment and Vanderbilt's Department of Mathematics.

The conference featured the keynote Shanks Lecture, plus 19 plenary lectures delivered by leading researchers in the fields of low-dimensional topology and geometry. These lectures presented new findings and results by mathematicians from a variety of career stages ranging from distinguished professors to postdoctoral scholars. There were a total of 74 participants in the conference, of whom 28 were graduate students and 16 postdocs.

The Shanks Conference on Low-dimensional Topology and Geometry highlighted the close interrelationships between geometry and topology in low dimensions and focused specifically on the powerful negative curvature and combinatorial techniques that have driven much of the research in low-dimensional topology in recent decades. These techniques are now yielding applications in contexts far removed from their original conception and are fueling many exciting developments. The conference brought together both young researchers and leading experts who have made substantial contributions to these areas, with the aim of providing a platform to discuss these developments, present recent results, and propose future directions of research.

Topology encompasses the study of spaces of varying shape and dimension, whether they be concrete like the surface of a doughnut or abstract like space of potential configurations of robots in a factory floor. In this theory, low (such as two or three) dimensional spaces play a distinguished role that departs in many respects from that of higher-dimensional spaces. The study of surfaces and 3-manifolds are thus of central importance in pure mathematics, with connections to many other branches of mathematics including algebraic geometry, number theory, complex analysis as well as more applied endeavors like theoretical physics and configuration spaces for mechanical systems. Geometry is the study of size, distance, and quantitative shape in a variety of spaces and settings. Geometry and topology are closely linked in low dimensions, and these interactions have led to profound breakthroughs in both areas. This inherent connection between geometry and topology pervaded William Thurston's revolutionary work in the 1980s that refocused the field of 3-manifold topology around a handful of bold geometric conjectures. By drawing on the work of many mathematicians and incorporating wide-ranging ideas from ergodic theory, combinatorial geometry, hyperbolic geometry, and group theory, this new paradigm in 3-manifold topology has now culminated in the remarkable proof of Thurston's Virtual Fibering Conjecture.

The Shanks conference revisited some of the ideas that emerged from this story and examined the tools and techniques that are now being refined and applied to broader contexts. Topics represented at the conference included hyperbolic 3-manifolds, moduli spaces of Riemann surfaces, the geometry and topology of curves on surfaces, surface bundles, Gromov-hyperbolic simplicial complexes, CAT(0) cube complexes, and many others.
